member.name: T:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Boards.Navio.INavioRCInputDevice
member.summary: Navio RC input device.

remarks.para: Difference Navio models use different methods for RC input. This interface provides a hardware model agnostic way to control the RC input and supported protocols.

Navio and Navio Plus use a GPIO pin which requires software PPM conversion, consuming significant processor resources and introducing latencies and inaccuracies. Additionally it is not feasible to support any other protocols than CPPM because alternative protocols such as SBUS usually require a much faster cycle detection rate.
Navio 2 uses an STM32 co-processor for "hardware" (microprocessor firmware) RC input with multiple protocols including CPPM and SBUS.

member.name: P:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Boards.Navio.INavioRCInputDevice.Channels
member.summary: PPM channel values.

member.name: P:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Boards.Navio.INavioRCInputDevice.Multiprotocol
member.summary: Indicates multiple protocols are supported, otherwise only CPPM is possible.

member.name: E:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Boards.Navio.INavioRCInputDevice.ChannelsChanged
member.summary: Fired after a new frame of data has been received and decoded into .

member.name: T:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Boards.Navio.INavioPwmDevice
member.summary: Navio PWM output device.

remarks.para: Difference Navio models use different methods for PWM output. This interface provides a hardware model agnostic way to control the PWM output and detect the channel capabilities.

Navio and Navio Plus use a PCA9685 hardware PWM chip which is limited to a single frequency and loses 3 of the 16 possible outputs by connecting to the RGB LED, although gaining hardware PWM for the LED (68 million colors).

Navio 2 uses an STM32 co-processor for "hardware" (microprocessor firmware) PWM output of up to 14 channels, but loses fidelity of the RGB LED (only 16 colors) because that is then connected to GPIO pins.

member.name: P:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Boards.Navio.INavioPwmDevice.CanDisable
member.summary: Indicates whether PWM can be disabled, i.e. must be enabled before it will generate output.

member.name: P:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Boards.Navio.INavioPwmDevice.Enabled
member.summary: Enables or disables PWM when possible.
member.remarks: Do not try to set false when is not true.
member.exception: Thrown when attempting to set the value to disabled when it is not supported.

member.name: P:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Boards.Navio.INavioPwmDevice.FrequencyPerChannel
member.summary: Indicates a different frequency can be set for each channel.

member.name: P:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Boards.Navio.INavioPwmDevice.Frequency
member.summary: Frequency for all channels in Hz.

remarks.para: When is true, reading this value returns the highest of all frequencies and writing it sets all channels to the same frequency. When is false, the device does not support multiple frequencies so all values are tied together.

When setting the frequency, the device clock and oscillator characteristics may cause the resulting frequency to be different to what was set. Read back the value after setting to get the actual value.
Some PWM devices do not tolerate high values and could be damaged if this is set too high, e.g. analog servos operate at much lower frequencies than digital servos. See for more information.

member.name: P:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Boards.Navio.INavioPwmDevice.FrequencyMinimum
member.summary: Minimum frequency supported in Hz.

member.name: P:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Boards.Navio.INavioPwmDevice.FrequencyMaximum
member.summary: Maximum frequency supported in Hz.

member.name: P:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Boards.Navio.INavioPwmDevice.WidthMinimum
member.summary: Minimum pulse width in fractions of milliseconds, based on the current .

member.name: P:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Boards.Navio.INavioPwmDevice.WidthMaximum
member.summary: Maximum pulse width in fractions of milliseconds, based on the current .

member.name: P:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Boards.Navio.INavioPwmDevice.Channels
member.summary: PWM channel pulse widths in milliseconds.
member.remarks: The can only be changed when the device supports independent frequencies per channel, i.e. is true.

member.summary: Clears all values and resets the device state to default (disabled).

member.summary: Reads the PWM channels from the device then updates the related properties.

member.name: P:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Boards.Navio.Internal.Navio1LedPwmDevice.Emlid#WindowsIot#Hardware#Boards#Navio#INavioPwmDevice#Frequency
member.summary: Frequency for all channels in Hz.

remarks.para: When is true, reading this value returns the highest of all frequencies and writing it sets all channels to the same frequency. When is false, the device does not support multiple frequencies so all values are tied together.

When setting the frequency, the device clock and oscillator characteristics may cause the resulting frequency to be different to what was set. Read back the value after setting to get the actual value.
Some PWM devices do not tolerate high values and could be damaged if this is set too high, e.g. analog servos operate at much lower frequencies than digital servos. See for more information.

member.name: P:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Boards.Navio.Internal.Navio1LedPwmDevice.Emlid#WindowsIot#Hardware#Boards#Navio#INavioPwmDevice#FrequencyPerChannel
member.summary: Indicates whether the frequency can be controlled individually for each channel.

remarks.para: When true, the of each in can be used to change the frequency of individual channels. The can still be used to set all channel frequencies at once, or get the highest frequency of all channels.
When false, only the value can be used and any attempt to change the frequency of individual channels will throw an error.

member.name: T:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Boards.Navio.Internal.Navio1RCInputDevice
member.summary: Navio Remote Control input hardware device.
member.remarks: Navio provides RC (receiver) input via a connector on it's servo rail mapped to GPIO pin 4. Navio+ has a logic level converter and you can connect receivers which generate both 3.3V and 5V signals. The older Navio model only has a built-in voltage divider in PPM Input that lowers the voltage level from 5V to 3.3V. So if you connect a 3.3V PPM device (which is rare) to the original Navio, no signal will not be detected.

member.summary: Hardware device provider for compatible boards.
member.remarks: Starting point from which consumers can gain access to all hardware devices without worrying about hardware detection or initialization.

member.name: F:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Boards.Navio.NavioDeviceProvider._lock
member.summary: Thread synchronization.

member.summary: Currently active board.

member.name: M:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Boards.Navio.NavioDeviceProvider.Detect
member.summary: Attempts auto-detection of the currently installed Navio board.
member.returns: Navio hardware model when detected, or null when failed.
member.remarks: Returns the existing model once initialized (it would not be safe to detect with hardware already in use). As the EEPROM ID is not accessible in Windows IoT, the FRAM device is used as the next best and safe probe for the hardware model. It is different in all current versions. In Navio 2 it doesn't exist. In Navio+ it exists at one address. In the original Navio it exists with two addresses (less RAM with high and low address split). The detection logic is thus: 1) See if the first FRAM address is available. No = Navio 2. 2) See if the second FRAM address is available. Yes = Navio, No = Navio+. TODO: Perform an additional test to really detect a Navio 2.

member.returns: Hardware interface for the requested model when successful.
member.remarks: The requested hardware model must be the same, otherwise any existing board is disposed and an attempt made to create a board of the new model.

member.name: T:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Components.Px4io.Px4ioPacket
member.summary: PX4IO serial interface protocol packet.

remarks.para: Communication is performed via writes to and reads from 16-bit virtual registers organized into pages of 255 registers each.
The first two bytes of each write select a page and offset address respectively. Subsequent reads and writes increment the offset within the page.
Some pages are read or write-only.
Note that some pages may permit offset values greater than 255, which can only be achieved by long writes. The offset does not wrap.
Writes to unimplemented registers are ignored. Reads from unimplemented registers return undefined values.

As convention, values that would be floating point in other parts of the PX4 system are expressed as signed integer values scaled by 10000, e.g.control values range from -10000..10000. Use the REG_TO_SIGNED and SIGNED_TO_REG macros to convert between register representation and the signed version, and REG_TO_FLOAT/FLOAT_TO_REG to convert to float.
Note that the implementation of readable pages prefers registers within readable pages to be densely packed. Page numbers do not need to be packed.

member.name: T:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Components.Mb85rcv.Mb85rc04vDevice
member.summary: MB85RC04V 512 byte FRAM (Ferroelectric Random Access Memory) chip (hardware device), connected via I2C.

remarks.para: The MB85RC04V is an FRAM (Ferroelectric Random Access Memory) chip in a configuration of 512 words 8 bits, using the ferroelectric process and silicon gate CMOS process technologies for forming the nonvolatile memory cells.
Unlike SRAM, the MB85RC04V is able to retain data without using a data backup battery.
The read/write endurance of the nonvolatile memory cells used for the MB85RC04V has improved to be at least 10^12 cycles, significantly outperforming other nonvolatile memory products in the number.
The MB85RC04V does not need a polling sequence after writing to the memory such as the case of Flash memory or E2PROM.
Data sheet: https://www.fujitsu.com/us/Images/MB85RC04V-DS501-00016-2v0-E.pdf

member.name: F:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Components.Mb85rcv.Mb85rc04vDevice.Density
member.summary: Density of this model.

member.summary: Maximum number of devices (chip number) for this model.

member.name: F:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Components.Mb85rcv.Mb85rc04vDevice.MemorySize
member.summary: Memory size in bytes.

member.name: F:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Components.Mb85rcv.Mb85rc04vDevice.DeviceAddressBitmask
member.summary: Bit mask for the A1 and A2 device address code.
member.remarks: The device address code identifies one device from up to 4 devices connected to the bus. Each MB85RC04V is given a unique 2 bits code on the device address pin (external hardware pin A2 and A1). The slave only responds if the received device address code is equal to this unique 2 bits code.
Shifted down 1 bit because the handles the read/write flag automatically (a.k.a. 7-bit addressing).

member.name: F:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Components.Mb85rcv.Mb85rc04vDevice.MemoryUpperAddressBitmask
member.summary: Bit mask for the memory upper address code.
member.remarks: This bit is not the setting bit for another chip/slave address, but the upper 1-bit setting bit for the memory address. Shifted down 1 bit because the handles the read/write flag automatically (a.k.a. 7-bit addressing).

member.name: F:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Components.Mb85rcv.Mb85rc04vDevice.MemoryLowerAddressCommandBytes
member.summary: Number bytes which make-up the memory address in commands.
member.remarks: The MS85RC04V chip has a complex memory addressing scheme with only the lower byte specified as part of the command request. The 9th bit is separated into the device address so it is necessary to interact with multiple I2C addresses to access all memory individually.

member.name: T:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Components.Mb85rcv.Mb85rcvDevice
member.summary: Base class for MB85RC#V FRAM (Ferroelectric Random Access Memory) family of chips (hardware devices), connected via I2C.

remarks.para: The MB85RC#V family are FRAM (Ferroelectric Random Access Memory) chips in different configurations, providing more or less words of memory, using the ferroelectric process and silicon gate CMOS process technologies for forming the nonvolatile memory cells.
Unlike SRAM, the MB85RC#V chips are able to retain data without using a data backup battery.
The read/write endurance of the nonvolatile memory cells used for the MB85RC#V has improved to be at least 10^12 cycles, significantly outperforming other nonvolatile memory products in the number.
The MB85RC#V chips do not need a polling sequence after writing to the memory such as the case of Flash memory or E2PROM.
MB85RC04V data sheet: https://www.fujitsu.com/us/Images/MB85RC04V-DS501-00016-2v0-E.pdf MB85RC256V data sheet: https://www.fujitsu.com/us/Images/MB85RC256V-DS501-00017-3v0-E.pdf
The "Device Address Code" has been renamed to "chip number" in code to help clarify documentation and avoid confusion of I2C and RAM address parameters.

member.name: F:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Components.Mb85rcv.Mb85rcvDevice.TypeCode
member.summary: Code which identifies the device type, and are fixed at 1010 for the MB85RC#V.

member.name: F:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Components.Mb85rcv.Mb85rcvDevice.DataI2cAddress
member.summary: 7-bit I2C address of the first chip on the bus.
member.remarks: When using multiple chips the chip address must be added.

member.name: F:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Components.Mb85rcv.Mb85rcvDevice.DeviceIdI2cAddress
member.summary: 7-bit I2C address used for chip identification.

remarks.para: The device ID sequence is as follows (Master = host, Slave = chip): 1) Master: Start of transaction. 2) Master: Byte 1 = 0XF8. 3) Master: Byte 2 = Address of chip to query, e.g. 0XA0, 0XA4, 0XA8, 0XAA. 4) Slave: Byte 3...5 device ID data bytes. 5) Master: End of transaction.

With read and write operations (bit 1) both 0XF8 and 0XF9 are used. Hence the device ID sequence for obtaining the device ID bytes is to call writing one byte as the set to the chip number to identify (full byte as data, not shifted down to 7-bit address) then reading the resulting 3 device ID bytes, all in one operation.

member.name: M:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Components.Mb85rcv.Mb85rcvDevice.GetI2cDeviceForMemoryAddress(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the required to communicate with a specific memory address.
member.param: Memory address. Leave zero when performing commands which operate on the current address.
member.remarks:
Because the chip mixes sub-address bits and flags with the slave address and the Windows cannot be modified after creation, it is necessary to use multiple instances for each.
This base class implementation is the least complex like newer/larger chips, only requiring different I2C addresses for the read/write flag (no memory address bits). Older chips should override this implementation to index into the additional I2C devices they need to access all memory addresses.

member.name: T:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Components.Mb85rcv.Mb85rc256vDevice
member.summary: MB85RC256V 32KiB FRAM (Ferroelectric Random Access Memory) chip (hardware device), connected via I2C.

remarks.para: The MB85RC256V is an FRAM (Ferroelectric Random Access Memory) chip in a configuration of 32,768 words 8 bits, using the ferroelectric process and silicon gate CMOS process technologies for forming the nonvolatile memory cells.
Unlike SRAM, the MB85RC256V is able to retain data without using a data backup battery.
The read/write endurance of the nonvolatile memory cells used for the MB85RC256V has improved to be at least 10^12 cycles, significantly outperforming other nonvolatile memory products in the number.
The MB85RC256V does not need a polling sequence after writing to the memory such as the case of Flash memory or E2PROM.
Data sheet: https://www.fujitsu.com/us/Images/MB85RC256V-DS501-00017-3v0-E.pdf

member.name: T:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Components.Pca9685.Pca9685Device
member.summary: PCA9685 PWM LED driver (hardware device), connected via I2C.
member.remarks:
The PCA9685 is a 16 channel, 12-bit PWM LED controller with I2C bus connection.
This class enables direct control of the device intended for internal use. If exposed to other users, it should wrapped by a thread safe class which coordinates access and deals with object lifetime (dispose). See http://www.nxp.com/documents/data_sheet/PCA9685.pdf for more information.

member.summary: Calculates the value from a desired frequency and clock speed.
member.remarks: Due to scaling only certain frequencies are possible. To get the resulting frequency from the desired frequency it is necessary to re-calculate the effective frequency back from the prescale, i.e. call .
member.param: Desired frequency in Hz. Must be between and to get a valid result.
member.returns: Calculated prescale value.
member.exception: Thrown when an invalid parameter is passed.
Thrown when parameters are passed which causes the resulting prescale to be higher than or lower than .

member.name: M:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Components.Pca9685.Pca9685Device.WriteFrequency(System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculates the prescale value from the frequency (according to ) then writes that register, then calls to update properties. Note the actual frequency may differ to the requested frequency due to clock scale (rounding).
member.remarks: The prescale can only be set during sleep mode. This method enters if necessary, then only if the device was awake before, calls afterwards. It's important not to start output unexpectedly to avoid damage, i.e. if the device was sleeping before, the frequency is changed without starting the oscillator.
member.param: Desired frequency to set in Hz.
member.returns: Effective frequency in Hz, read-back and recalculated after setting the desired frequency. Frequency in Hz. Related properties are also updated.
member.exception: Thrown when is less than or greater than .

member.name: M:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Components.Pca9685.Pca9685Device.Clear
member.summary: Clears all channels cleanly, then updates all .
member.remarks: To "cleanly" clear the channels, it is necessary to first ensure they are not disabled, set them to zero, then disable them. Otherwise the ON value and the low OFF value remain because writes are ignored when the OFF channel bit 12 is already set.

member.name: F:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Components.Pca9685.Pca9685Mode1Bits.Sleep
member.summary: Enables or disables low-power mode (oscillator off).

remarks.para: It takes 500 s maximum for the oscillator to be up and running once sleep bit has been set to 0. Timings on LED# outputs are not guaranteed if PWM control registers are accessed within the 500 s window. There is no start-up delay required when using the external clock pin as the PWM clock.
No PWM control is possible when the oscillator is off.
When the oscillator is off (sleep mode) the LED# outputs cannot be turned on, off or dimmed/blinked.

member.name: F:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Components.Pca9685.Pca9685Mode1Bits.AutoIncrement
member.summary: When the Auto Increment flag is set the control register is automatically incremented after a read or write. This allows the user to program the registers sequentially.

member.name: F:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Components.Pca9685.Pca9685Mode1Bits.ExternalClock
member.summary: Enables or disables the

remarks.para: To use the external clock pin, this bit must be set by the following sequence:

list.item: Set the sleep bit in mode 1. This turns off the internal oscillator.
Set both the sleep and external clock bits in mode 1.The switch is now made. The external clock can be active during the switch because the sleep bit is set.

remarks.para: This bit is a "sticky bit", that is, it cannot be cleared by writing a 0 to it. The external clock bit can only be cleared by a power cycle or software reset. External clock range is DC to 50 MHz. The frequency is calculated as: refresh rate = external clock / (4096 * (prescale + 1))

member.name: F:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Components.Pca9685.Pca9685Mode1Bits.Restart
member.summary: Enables or disables the
member.remarks: Reading shows the state of restart logic. Write 1 to this bit to clear it. Writing 0 has no effect.

member.summary: Bitmask for the register.

member.summary: No bits set.

member.summary: Active low output enable (OUTNE) bit 0.

member.name: F:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Components.Pca9685.Pca9685Mode2Bits.OutputActiveLow1
member.summary: Active low output enable (OUTNE) bit 1.

member.name: F:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Components.Pca9685.Pca9685Mode2Bits.OutputDrive
member.summary: Selects the LED drive mode.
member.remarks: When set, the 16 LED# outputs are configured with a totem pole structure. When cleared, the 16 LED# outputs are configured with an open-drain structure. Power on default is set.

member.name: F:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Components.Pca9685.Pca9685Mode2Bits.OutputChange
member.summary: Selects the output change mode.

remarks.para: When set, outputs change on ACK. Update on ACK requires all 4 PWM channel registers to be loaded before outputs will change on the last ACK.

When cleared, outputs change on STOP. Change of the outputs at the STOP command allows synchronizing outputs of more than one PCA9685. Applicable to registers from 06h (LED0_ON_L) to 45h (LED15_OFF_H) only. 1 or more registers can be written, in any order, before STOP.
Power on default is cleared.

member.name: F:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Components.Pca9685.Pca9685Mode2Bits.OutputInvert
member.summary: Inverts output when OE set. Sets the value to use when an external driver is used.

remarks.para: Normal LEDs can be driven directly in either mode. Some newer LEDs include integrated Zener diodes to limit voltage transients, reduce EMI, protect the LEDs and these must be driven only in the open-drain mode to prevent overheating the IC.
Power on reset default state of LED# output pins is LOW and this option is not enabled.

member.name: T:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Protocols.Ppm.CppmDecoder
member.summary: PPM decoder for the CPPM protocol.
member.remarks:
A complete CPPM frame is about 22.5 ms (can vary between manufacturer). Signal low state is about 0.3 ms but sometimes a bit longer (). It begins with a start pulse (state high for more than 2 ms ). Each channel (up to 8) is encoded by the time of the high state (CPPM high state + 0.3 x (PPM low state) = servo PPM pulse width).
See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pulse-position_modulation for more information.

member.name: F:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Protocols.Ppm.CppmDecoder.ChannelCount
member.summary: Number of channels in a standard CPPM frame.

member.name: F:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Protocols.Ppm.CppmDecoder.SyncLengthMinimum
member.summary: Minimum sync (PPM cycle) length in microseconds.

member.name: F:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Protocols.Ppm.CppmDecoder.LowLimit
member.summary: Maximum time in microseconds which a PPM signal may be low before it is considered invalid for CPPM.
member.remarks: Some specifications state 0.3ms is expected, but 0.4-0.5ms has been observed. We also add a bit more time for inaccuracies and differences between manufacturers.

member.summary: Creates an instance.

member.name: T:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Protocols.Ppm.PpmFrame
member.summary: PPM frame data, a sequence of one or more PPM values sent together at a time.
member.remarks: Used as a standard variable container for both "PPM" (single channel) and other multi-channel protocols such as CPPM (a.k.a. PPM-Sum). The value of each channel depends on the protocol, i.e. what the start and end PPM lengths are and polarity (high or low as delimiter).

member.name: F:Emlid.WindowsIot.Hardware.Protocols.Pwm.PwmPulse.ServoSafeFrequency
member.summary: Frequency in Hz which many analog servos support.
member.remarks: Always check the specification of your servo before enabling output to avoid damage! Digital servos are capable of frequencies over 100Hz, some between 300-400Hz and higher. Some analog servos may even have trouble with 50Hz, but as most other autopilots are using 50Hz are default we choose this as an acceptable default.
